word.entryDescription: the number 19
word.entryExample: There are nineteen students in the class.

word.entryDescription: in the position of number nine when we count
word.entryExample: Alex got a bike for his ninth birthday.

word.entryDescription: no longer, not any more
word.entryExample: The cat was hungry because there was no more food in the kitchen.

word.entryDescription: not anyone, nobody
word.entryExample: Didn't you think it was strange no-one was free this weekend?

word.entryDescription: not anybody
word.entryExample: Luckily, nobody was hurt.

word.entryDescription: making a lot of unwelcome sound
word.entryExample: My class is very noisy.

word.entryDescription: books and writing about facts, real people and real events
word.entryExample: I like fiction and non-fiction books.

word.entryDescription: a journey in leisure time
word.entryExample: We have to pay more and more attention to non-work travel because it’s becoming a much more significant part of the total travel.

word.entryDescription: used when mentioning two things that are not true or do not happen
word.entryExample: 'I don't like this book.' 'Nor do I'

word.entryDescription: the direction that is normally at the top of a map; opposite south
word.entryExample: It's cold in the north of the country.

word.entryDescription: a continent made up of all the countries in the upper half of America, stretching from Panama and the Caribbean up to Canada and Greenland
word.entryExample: Temperate rainforests are located in western North America, south eastern Australia and New Zealand.

word.entryDescription: the northern end of the earth's axis of rotation,
word.entryExample: It's cold and snowy at the North Pole.

word.entryDescription: the part of the face between your mouth and your eyes
word.entryExample: The ball hit my friend on the nose.

word.entryDescription: a short time after an event or time that has already been mentioned
word.entryExample: Not long afterwards came another request for the artist to paint the Princess.

word.entryDescription: used for presenting an additional argument
word.entryExample: Not only does the death penalty send a message that killing is acceptable, but innocent people might also be killed.

word.entryDescription: something you write down in a lesson, from a book, etc so that you can refer to it later
word.entryExample: You should go back and look at your notes regularly.

word.entryDescription: not anything
word.entryExample: There's nothing on at the youth club tonight. It's closed!

word.entryDescription: a long written story, usually in the form of a book
word.entryExample: I write short stories and am halfway through my first novel.

word.entryDescription: at the present time
word.entryExample: I'm not hungry now.

word.entryDescription: somebody who looks after sick or injured people, or an assistant to a doctor
word.entryExample: Is your mum a nurse here?

word.entryDescription: the job of caring for sick or injured people
word.entryExample: Florence Nightingale is famous for improving nursing and healthcare around the world.

word.entryDescription: a dry fruit inside a hard shell which grows on a tree
word.entryExample: I like chocolate with nuts in it.

word.entryDescription: the substances that you eat and drink which are good for your health and growth
word.entryExample: The dietician who produced my nutrition programme works in a clinic in Tokyo.

word.entryDescription: the amount of nutritional substances (i.e. substances that help you stay healthy) in some food
word.entryExample: Don't cook vegetables for too long. It lessens their nutritional value.

word.entryDescription: a calm, pleasant or attractive place in the middle of area which is not calm, pleasant or attractive
word.entryExample: The Old Town is an architectural oasis in an otherwise grim and modern city.

word.entryDescription: a flattened cake of baked oatmeal (crushed oats used in cooking)
word.entryExample: In the Middle Ages, poorer people used to have oatcakes or porridge for breakfast.

word.entryDescription: the state of being very fat
word.entryExample: Some processed food has been linked to an increase in health problems such as obesity.

word.entryDescription: to follow an order, or behave according to a rule
word.entryExample: Everyone obeyed the captain's orders.

word.entryDescription: something that you are always thinking about
word.entryExample: This modern obsession with health and exercise can have very harmful effects.
What is your present occupation?

word.entryDescription: to fill your time; to be busy doing something
word.entryExample: How will you occupy your time as a summer camp group leader?

word.entryDescription: a very large sea
word.entryExample: This place is amazing. It’s really small and there’s ocean all around.

word.entryDescription: strong movement of the water in the ocean in one direction
word.entryExample: Seasonal change is related to, among other things, ocean currents and solar radiation.

word.entryDescription: a sea creature with a soft round body and eight long arm-like parts
word.entryExample: Octopuses aren't fish but they live in the sea.

word.entryDescription: used to emphasise that you are saying 'yes' when giving permission
word.entryExample: Can you help me with the fire? Of course, Jack.

word.entryDescription: very rude, upsetting or unpleasant
word.entryExample: That comment was worse than disrespectful, it was offensive!

word.entryDescription: to ask someone if they would like something that you can provide
word.entryExample: Rod Stewart offered to give a percentage of his royalties for that song to charity.

word.entryDescription: a place where people work, usually at desks
word.entryExample: Is your office near here?

word.entryDescription: used when you are reacting to something to show that you are happy, disappointed, angry etc about it
word.entryExample: Oh, no! Poor you!

word.entryDescription: a thick liquid that is found in rock underground from which petrol is produced
word.entryExample: Fossil fuels include gas, oil and coal.

word.entryDescription: an accident where oil is released into a large body of water, damaging the environment
word.entryExample: Oil spills are an example of pollution.

word.entryDescription: something that is old has lived or existed for a long time
word.entryExample: How old is this cat?

word.entryDescription: not modern; no longer fashionable; of the past
word.entryExample: This house has a rather old-fashioned kitchen.

word.entryDescription: to get the money provided by the government to people who are sick, unemployed, or have little money
word.entryExample: I've been on benefits for three years now.
Let's go on foot. It's quicker.

word.entryDescription: to have a good relationship with somebody
word.entryExample: Aunt Rebecca is not on good terms with her brother, my father.

word.entryDescription: for sale for a short time at a cheaper price than usual
word.entryExample: Tomatoes are on offer this week.

word.entryDescription: switched on, but not being used
word.entryExample: We can save energy by turning off electrical appliances at the wall instead of leaving them on standby.

word.entryDescription: in the area where the land and sea meet
word.entryExample: If we had stayed on the coast, I could have swum in the sea every day.

word.entryDescription: in a place where two streets, lines or edges meet
word.entryExample: The post office is on the corner of Main and Long Street.
